page.title: 17LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: LIFE WAS LEISURELY. EVERYTHING WAS HORSE-DRAWN. MOST HOUSES HAD EARTH CLOSETS WHICH WERE CLEANED OUT AT INTERVALS BY MEN EMPLOYED BY THE LOCAL COUNCIL. IT WAS NOT UNTIL THE LATE 1920'S THAT STAINDROP HAD ELECTRICITY. BEFORE THAT A RATHER POOR GAS SUPPLY PROVIDED A FORM OF LIGHTING. FEW HOUSES HAD PIPED WATER,MOST DEPENDED ON THE MANY PUMPS IN THE VILLAGE. THE RABY ESTATE EMPLOYED MOST OF THE MEN, OTHERS WALKED TO WORK AT NEARBY PITS. AGRICULTURE EMPLOYED MANY MORE MEN THAN NOW, AGAIN HORSES DOING PLOUGHING REAPING AND SOWING. WITH SO MANY HORSES, THERE WAS A NEED FOR BLACKSMITHS AND THERE WERE ALWAYS TWO IN THE VILLAGE. NEWSPAPERS WERE BROUGHT BY HORSE AND TRAP FROM WINSTON STATION. CATTLE WERE DRIVEN TO BARNARD .
